prior_works.title: Communication-Efficient Learning of Deep Networks from Decentralized Data (FedAvg)
prior_works.authors: H. Brendan McMahan, Eider Moore, Daniel Ramage, Seth Hampson, Blaise Agüera y Arcas
prior_works.role: Foundational federated learning algorithm and training paradigm
prior_works.relationship_sentence: HYPERION is instantiated within the standard FL pipeline established by FedAvg, but replaces purely Euclidean updates with hyperspherical representations and alignment/purification steps tailored to graph data and noisy labels.

prior_works.title: SphereFace: Deep Hypersphere Embedding for Face Recognition
prior_works.authors: Weiyang Liu, Yandong Wen, Zhiding Yu, Meng Yang
prior_works.role: Introduced unit-norm embeddings and angular-margin losses on a hypersphere
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The client-side fine-grained hypersphere alignment in HYPERION builds on the insight from SphereFace that normalized, angular geometry yields tighter intra-class compactness and clearer inter-class separation.

prior_works.title: ArcFace: Additive Angular Margin Loss for Deep Face Recognition
prior_works.authors: Jiankang Deng, Jia Guo, Niannan Xue, Stefanos Zafeiriou
prior_works.role: Refined angular-margin classification to enforce discriminative hyperspherical geometry
prior_works.relationship_sentence: HYPERION’s alignment objective leverages ArcFace-style angular constraints to regulate edge-mediated error propagation and capture intra-class topological nuances through precise angle-based separation.

prior_works.title: Prototypical Networks for Few-shot Learning
prior_works.authors: Jake Snell, Kevin Swersky, Richard S. Zemel
prior_works.role: Established class prototypes as geometric anchors in embedding space
prior_works.relationship_sentence: HYPERION’s unified hyperspherical space and class-aware alignment/purification are inspired by prototype-centric reasoning, using spherical class anchors to guide consistent cross-client graph representations.

prior_works.title: MOON: Model-Contrastive Federated Learning
prior_works.authors: Qinbin Li, Bingsheng He, Dawn Song
prior_works.role: Introduced cosine-based representation alignment to mitigate client drift in FL
prior_works.relationship_sentence: HYPERION extends MOON’s cosine/angle-based alignment principle by performing fine-grained hyperspherical alignment of graph embeddings, explicitly addressing topology-driven intra-class variation under label noise.

prior_works.title: Robust Aggregation for Federated Learning via Median and Geometric Median
prior_works.authors: Venkatakrishna Pillutla, Sham Kakade, Zaid Harchaoui
prior_works.role: Pioneered geometry-aware robust server aggregation against corrupted updates
prior_works.relationship_sentence: HYPERION’s geometric-aware hyperspherical purification module parallels the idea of robust geometric aggregation, adapting it to spherical manifolds and class-conditional representations to filter label-induced noise.

prior_works.title: Co-teaching: Robust Training of Deep Neural Networks with Extremely Noisy Labels
prior_works.authors: Bo Han, Quanming Yao, Xingrui Yu, Gang Niu, Miao Xu, Weihua Hu, Ivor W. Tsang, Masashi Sugiyama
prior_works.role: Canonical noisy-label learning via mutual sample selection and purification
prior_works.relationship_sentence: HYPERION provides a geometric alternative to sample/label purification by detecting and suppressing noise through angular inconsistency on the hypersphere, an idea conceptually related to Co-teaching’s purification but realized via manifold geometry and federation.

synthesis_narrative:
HYPERION’s core idea—a unified hyperspherical space enabling fine-grained alignment on clients and geometric purification on the server—sits at the intersection of angular metric learning and federated alignment/robustness. SphereFace and ArcFace established that constraining representations to the unit sphere with angular-margin losses delivers robust intra-class compactness and inter-class separation. HYPERION transposes these principles from images to graph embeddings, exploiting angular geometry to modulate edge-mediated message passing and to parse intra-class topological diversity. Prototypical Networks further contributed the notion of class-centric geometric anchors; HYPERION leverages prototype-like anchors on the hypersphere to coordinate class-wise alignment across heterogeneous clients.

Within federated learning, FedAvg provides the training substrate, while MOON’s cosine-based representation alignment motivates HYPERION’s angle-aware, client-side objectives that resist client drift in non-iid graph settings. At the server, robust aggregation via geometric median (Pillutla et al.) informs HYPERION’s geometric-aware purification: instead of aggregating raw parameters, it filters noisy contributions in a manifold-aware way by operating on normalized, class-conditional spherical embeddings. Finally, Co-teaching’s success in noisy-label regimes shaped HYPERION’s philosophy of selective purification; yet, HYPERION operationalizes purification through angular consistency tests and hyperspherical statistics rather than small-loss heuristics. Together, these works directly inspire HYPERION’s fine-grained hypersphere alignment to curb error propagation on graphs and its hyperspherical purification to mitigate undetected label noise, yielding a robust federated graph learning framework.
